content.question:
Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A small sled slides across a rough horizontal table with an initial velocity <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the sled and the table is <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></math>. A string connects the sled to a device on the ground. The device maintains constant tension <math alttext="F sub T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>T</mi></msub></math> in the string by unwinding the string as the sled slides to the right. The total mass of the sled is <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math>. The string is attached to the device at <math alttext="x equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> and at a height of <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The horizontal position of the sled is represented by <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. Express all algebraic answers in terms of <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math>, <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></math>, <math alttext="F sub T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>T</mi></msub></math>, <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>, <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

(a) On the dot below that represents the sled, draw and label the forces (not components) that are exerted on the sled a short time after <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> but before the sled has come to rest. Each force must be represented by a distinct arrow starting on, and pointing away from, the dot.

frqParts.text:
Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A small sled slides across a rough horizontal table with an initial velocity <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the sled and the table is <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></math>. A string connects the sled to a device on the ground. The device maintains constant tension <math alttext="F sub T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>T</mi></msub></math> in the string by unwinding the string as the sled slides to the right. The total mass of the sled is <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math>. The string is attached to the device at <math alttext="x equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> and at a height of <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The horizontal position of the sled is represented by <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. Express all algebraic answers in terms of <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math>, <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></math>, <math alttext="F sub T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>T</mi></msub></math>, <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>, <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

(a) On the dot below that represents the sled, draw and label the forces (not components) that are exerted on the sled a short time after <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> but before the sled has come to rest. Each force must be represented by a distinct arrow starting on, and pointing away from, the dot.

(b) Determine an expression for the angle <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math> that the string makes with the vertical when the sled has traveled a horizontal distance <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>.

(c)

i. Derive an expression for the normal force <math alttext="F sub N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>N</mi></msub></math> exerted on the sled by the table as a function of the position <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>.

ii. Derive an expression for the magnitude of the net horizontal force <math alttext="F sub net" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>net</mi></msub></math> exerted on the sled as a function of the position <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>.

(d) Derive an expression for the work <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>W</mi></math> done by the string on the sled as the sled moves from <math alttext="x equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> to <math alttext="x equals L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>L</mi></math>.

(e) The sled comes to rest after traveling a horizontal distance <math alttext="x equals 2 L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>L</mi></math>. As the system slides from <math alttext="x equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> to <math alttext="x equals L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>L</mi></math>, the energy dissipated by friction is <math alttext="E sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. As the sled slides from <math alttext="x equals L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>L</mi></math> to <math alttext="x equals 2 L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>L</mi></math>, the energy dissipated by friction is <math alttext="E sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. Is <math alttext="E sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> greater than, less than, or equal to <math alttext="E sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> ?
___ <math alttext="E sub 1 is greater than E sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>           ___ <math alttext="E sub 1 is less than E sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>           ___ <math alttext="E sub 1 equals E sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>
Justify your answer.

skill.text: 1.A: Create diagrams, tables, charts, or schematics to represent physical situations.
